pullRequest.title: migrate OpenJDK 1.8 and 11 from travis to github actions
pullRequest.bodyText:
Also includes QA checks
As requested on mailing list, starts the migration away from Travis CI.
Checklist
For all pull requests:

 Confirm you have read the contribution guidelines
 You have sent a Contribution Licence Agreement (CLA) as necessary (not required for small changes, e.g., fixing typos in documentation)
 Make sure the first PR targets the master branch, eventual backports will be managed later. This can be ignored if the PR is fixing an issue that only happens in a specific branch, but not in newer ones.
 The changes are not breaking the build in downstream projects using SNAPSHOT dependencies, GeoWebCache and GeoServer (there is an automatic PR check verifying this, check this when it turns green).

The following are required only for core and extension modules (they are welcomed, but not required, for unsupported modules):

[N/A] There is an issue in Jira describing the bug/task/new feature (a notable exemptions is, changes not visible to end users). The ticket is for the GeoTools project, if the issue was found elsewhere it's a good practice to link to the origin ticket/issue.
 The pull request contains changes related to a single objective. If multiple focuses cannot be avoided, each one is in its own commit and has a separate ticket describing it.
 PR for bug fixes and small new features are presented as a single commit
[N/A] Commit message(s) must be in the form "[GEOT-XYZW] Title of the Jira ticket"
[N/A] New unit tests have been added covering the changes
 This PR passes all existing unit tests (test results will be reported by travis-ci after opening this PR)
 This PR passes the QA checks (QA checks results will be reported by travis-ci after opening this PR)
[N/A] Documentation has been updated accordingly.

Submitting the PR does not require you to check all items, but by the time it gets merged, they should be either satisfied or inapplicable.

nodes.bodyText:
Hey @bradh thanks a ton for doing this!
Just a note, I believe we need sphinx here too, the maven build in GeoTools builds also the docs (it's not a separate build like in GeoServer).
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,73 @@
+name: Linux with OpenJDK 1.8 and OpenJDK 11 GitHub CI
+
+on: [pull_request]
+
+env:
+  MAVEN_OPTS: -Dmaven.wagon.httpconnectionManager.ttlSeconds=25 -Dmaven.wagon.http.retryHandler.count=3
+
+jobs:
+  openjdk8:
+    runs-on: [ubuntu-18.04]
+    steps:
+    - uses: actions/checkout@v2
+    - name: Set up JDK 1.8
+      uses: actions/setup-java@v1
+      with:
+        java-version: 8
+    - name: Maven repository caching
+      uses: actions/cache@v2
+      with:
+        path: ~/.m2/repository
+        key: ${{ runner.os }}-maven-${{ hashFiles('**/pom.xml') }}
+        restore-keys: |
+          ${{ runner.os }}-maven-
+    - name: Build with Maven
+      run: |
+        mvn -B clean install -Dfmt.skip=true -Dall -T2 --file pom.xml

nodes.bodyText: What happened here, Java 8 is showing the same behavior?

commit.message: ci: migrate from travis to github actions

afterCommit.message: ci: migrate from travis to github actions

nodes.bodyText:
Everything looks good, just have a hesitation about this title... it's long and makes it harder to find at a glance a particular build in the GitHub PR checks:

Just calling it "Linux" or "Linux GitHub CI" would probably be enough, the name of the job is added at the end and clarifies which bit of the build is executed. E.g. may look like:
``Linux GitHub CI / openjdk11 (pull request)"
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,85 @@
+name: Linux with OpenJDK 1.8 and OpenJDK 11 GitHub CI

commit.message: ci: shorten Linux workflow display name
ci: add fail at end flag to QA build
